content: today we're going to make a versatile
set of buildings inspired by and similar to but definitely not the same as those
great kits offered by Games Workshop our main material will once again be
chipboard for those of you new to the channel this is graphics medium
chipboard and you can buy it through me as an Amazon affiliate if you like using
the link in the description below it's good stuff because it's a sixteenth of
an inch thick very sturdy takes glue and paint well
can be cut with a utility knife and is very cheap so draw out a grid of
rectangles two inch by three and a quarter of an inch the side of a
building will consist of any number of panels that you want so I'm just going
to select a shape here and now this is important above your topmost row of
panels measure out another row that's only 3/4 of an inch tall like this
you'll see why later so cut this out now draw an arched window on some
chipboard for yourself and cut it out keep it this is going to be your master
template use it to trace windows into some or all the panels whatever you like
Center them horizontally in each panel I recommend you keep the bottom of the
window 3/4 of an inch from the bottom of the panel again the bottom of the panel
would be where you drew the line cut them out with your utility knife just do
it freehand it really isn't as hard as it looks
now we'll apply what we'll call Bandung
writ many strips of chipboard that are quarter-inch wide use glue stick or a
thin application of white PVA glue to attach the banding start with all the
vertical pieces first you want them centered over the lines you originally
drew but since you can't see them when you're attaching the strip just eyeball
it centering it between the windows that you cut out note that the bands on the
outer ends need to be 1/2 hanging off the wall like this that ensures that
your windows are still centered but it also serves another purpose which you'll
see later on after all the vertical strips are done chop and apply all the
horizontal bits now also applied banding to the other side this will eventually
be the inside of the building but with one exception on that edge that's going
to be the corner where the two walls are going to meet don't attach a vertical
band and make the horizontal pieces and flush with main body like you see here
then go ahead and make an entire another
wall be careful that you establish the correct side of it as being the corner
which we're going to attach the other one to and on that note let's attach
them foamboard not dollar-store foam board but the good stuff from like
michael's or even the grocery store ensure that the corner is square and
then go ahead and cut out a rough shape the rougher the cut the better since
this is going to be like ruined concrete dry fit the walls so you know exactly
where they need to be in order for that outer corner to meet up then use hot
glue to attach one of the walls to the base
and then hot glue the other wall to the base since this is foam you'll have a
few seconds to slide and reposition things if you need to before the glue
cools now notice there's a small channel in the corner created by those banding
overhangs use that to apply some hot glue and secure the corners together
then cut more floors out of foam board and attach them with hot glue the
horizontal banding you applied serves as the connection point if you want and cut
holes in the floor to give it some character then I took some needlepoint
mesh sometimes called granny grating and cut some random pieces and just attach
them with white PVA glue and some bits of cork hot glue down and
random spots some toothpicks break them in half and insert them into the foam to
simulate exposed rebar
here's some gothic looking beads I found at the craft store any kind of Victorian
flat charm will work these were like two bucks for a pack of ten I'm going to
take them and cut them in half with my wire cutters and then white glue them
onto each panel in a repeating design like this now take some double
corrugated cardboard and cut out eight of this shape and make sure that the
corrugation is exposed along the long edge like this which will give us lots
of strength when we hot glue them apply corrugation cladding again if you're new
this is just very lightweight 60 pound cardstock or even plain old printer
paper will do then hot glue these to the building
along the vertical banding which as you recall is also a quarter inch wide it's
almost as if we planned it that way now right about this time I realized I
wanted to do something a little different with the upper floors so I
tore all that stuff off get some cereal box cardstock this is thinner and easier
to do detail cutting with cut a two inch square then cut a slightly smaller
square out of granny grating and attach it with a thin layer of white glue and
lastly cut an even slightly smaller square from cereal box and cut out a
cross pattern this is easier than you think
draw a line from corner to corner then draw two more lines one on each side
offset by about a sixteenth of an inch just eyeball it like I do here and now
you can cut out four triangles freehand leaving a roughly a Finch frame like to
see here takes about one minute to do each of these
attach it with some white glue and you have a floor panel make a whole bunch of
these then hot glue them to the floor four ones at the perimeter just cut them
to the correct shape with scissors or a knife before you glue them down
now I did go and buy some good Matt gray spray primer from the crafting store two
reasons one it'll take a hundred times longer to brush on a base coat and two
there's plastic in this piece the grading and acrylic craft paint will rub
right off that with no effort so a proper primer was in order I ate the
dark gray one to save time I'll take a bone or a cream color and lightly dry
brush all of the wall surfaces inside and out make sure to Nick the banding
then take a metallic gold and paint the
bead chains just an over brushes fine I didn't worry about getting into the
nooks and crannies next up a shiny silver ish metallic solid coat on all
the floor paneling and then a black wash you could apply
this over the entire piece I've tried that and I actually ended up liking the
walls a bit cleaner so I only applied it on the floors all levels including the
bottom one and don't be shy with it it will dry a lot lighter so it should look
really dark and messy when it's wet for the concrete on the bottom level very
simple dry brush with dark grey then grey then white with less and less
pressure for each color and lastly to give some depth I'm just going to use
black in my airbrush and do shadows in all the corners okay so that's the basic
idea now let's play around a bit here I've prepared a manufactory note the
rectangular windows and a smorgasbord of gears and other Victorian bits ready to
be attached check your attic if you have old collections of connects
they make awesome steampunk bits and so do the technics specialty line from
Legos so here we go I've attached a bunch of
stuff and also drilled two holes and ran lead wires in preparation for custom
lighting here's the parts for the circuit it's going to be two yellow LEDs
in parallel on a three volt battery if you need a refresher on how to design
fine parts and build this circuit revisit episode 56 so here it is
assembled of black bombed from there I just took some cheap metallic copper and
did a very heavy dry brush all over being sporadic keeping my brushstrokes
in mostly the same direction then did the same with a metallic silver but with
much lighter less pressure
so the floor panels inside it was the opposite lead with heavy silver and then
Nick with copper here again is the circuit ready for installation I mounted
the LEDs inside two random beads from my bin done beautiful the video really
doesn't do it justice in real life this thing looks like ancient oily metal I
can't believe the results from such cheap paints and dead simple technique I
mean it literally took three minutes to do the metallic tones for the entire
building let the detail do the work for you the more bits the textures you have
the better your over brush will look take advantage of those old toys and
make it them irregularly and before we go to the table I'd like to take a
moment to thank all wcv sponsors this week I draw your attention to dungeon
cast by Dan vicini Dan's designs are full on custom resin casts he's
currently focusing on one and a quarter inch grid tiles destined for box sets
with valuable D&D scenarios in them basically an evening in a box so click
the link in the description below and check out the dungeon cast Facebook page
so these take four to six hours apiece from my experience there's no benefit to
assembly lining them so you can sit down and make one at a time great set piece
for your role-playing game or those of you who are familiar with Warhammer 40k
know exactly what I've done here I knew that a panel is two inches wide from
measuring a sprue that my friend bought so from there I just reverse engineered
everything by looking at pictures and other YouTube tutorials for painting
those DW kits here I've made to basilica Bend stratums
one manufacturer and one sanctum Imperialis with a balcony this buildings
actually not done yet as of this video you can see it's kind of flat I need to
do some more roughing it up moral of the story is keep your spare
beads and bits and costume jewelry hoard it my storage bin was overflowing but I
kept on and sure enough this project came around and I didn't have to buy
anything I eat into most of that bin drastically
reduced my inventory and got some good looking scenery out of it these are
sturdy I'd wager they're just as easy to break as the real GW plastic kits may be
a little more difficult since they do have some flexibility tool they're not
brittle I did elect to use a ground floor instead of leaving it open because
that makes it very clear whether a model is quote within the terrain or not and
that's relevant for 40k and I did the ground floors mostly as busted up
concrete so that the look in place on any gaming mat
so I am wild Locke thank you for joining me and I'll see you next time
you
